Chalukya style of Architecture

The Chalukyas of Badami (Vatapi) made significant contributions to Indian temple architecture. They built hundreds of temples in Aihole (the cradle of Indian temple architecture), Badami, and Pattadakal (UNESCO site). Their style was a blend of the Nagara (North) and Dravida (South) styles, known as the Vesara style.

ЁЯСС
Pulakeshin II: Lord of the South

Pulakeshin II (610тАУ642 CE) was the greatest ruler of this dynasty. He defeated Harshavardhana on the banks of the Narmada River and assumed the title 'Dakshinapatheshvara'. His court poet Ravikirti wrote the famous Aihole inscription.

тЪФя╕П
Rivalry with the Pallavas

Their conflict with the Pallavas continued for generations. Ultimately, the Pallava king Narasimhavarman I invaded Badami, and Pulakeshin II was killed in battle. In the mid-8th century, their feudatory Dantidurga (Rashtrakuta) defeated Kirtivarman II, bringing an end to this dynasty.
